entry.string:
# this makes a new canvas ÑÊa fullscreen place to draw using Field's graphics system # obviously, you only have to do this once canvas = getFullscreenCanvas()
# if you wanted a window you could do something like: # canvas = getWindowedCanvas(bounds=(30,50,100,200))

# here we make a new GLSLang shader "from" this element # a GLSLang shader is a program that transforms, creates and draws geometry # such programs run on your graphics hardware rather than your CPU
# all 'makeShaderFromElement' this does is add three new properties to this element containing some default GLSLang program, which means that we can edit the code using this text editor (look at the drop down box at the top of the editor) shader = makeShaderFromElement(_self)
# having made a shader, it won't do anything unless we attach it to the canvas # again ÑÊwe only have to do this once. canvas << shader
# obviously, as you are writing your GLSLang program you'll want to update the shader Ñ use the button that appears at the top of this editor

# to draw a triangle we need to make a 'DynamicMesh' ÑÊwhich is a container for geometry that can grow and shrink dynamically
mesh = dynamicMesh()
# we haven't drawn anything into it, but when we do, we want it to appear in the canvas, and we want it to be "shaded" by our shader. So we attach it to the shader
shader << mesh

# we made a mesh, and we attached it to a shader, but it doesn't contain any geometry
# three ways of drawing a triangle
# 'with' means that we're drawing into it. At the start of a 'with' everything inside 'mesh' is deleted, and at the end, you're done with it and you can send it to the graphics system with mesh: # here we add a vertex at 0,0,0 mesh ** Vector3(0,0,0) # and another mesh ** Vector3(1,0,0) # and another mesh ** Vector3(0,1,0) # now we have three vertices. But to see anything we need to say "make those three vertices into a triangle mesh ** [0,1,2]
# here's another way with mesh: mesh.nextFace(Vector3(0,0,0), Vector3(1,0,0), Vector3(0,1,0))
# and here's one more way with mesh: mesh ** mesh ** [Vector3(0,0,0), Vector3(1,0,0), Vector3(0,1,0)]
# at this point you should see a dark grey triangle in the canvas. Why is it dark grey? select the "make a new GLSLang Shader" box and click on the box at the top of the text editor and explore the 'XXX shader' properties

from field.graphics.core import PointList
# let's make another shader (a transulcent white shader) pointShader = makeShaderFromElement(_self) canvas << pointShader
# and we'll make a 'point list' with a lot of points numPoints = 100000 list = PointList(CoordinateFrame()) list.rebuildVertex(numPoints)
pointShader<< list
# note how this call takes a while Ñ ok to prototype with, but you wouldn't want to try to animate like this vertex = list.vertex() for n in range(0, vertex.capacity()): vertex.put(Math.random())
# this is how we set a 'uniform' variable in a shader pointShader.extraColor=Vector4(1,1,1,0.1)

# this is much faster than doing it in Python and yet we retain a lot of the dynamism def doRandom(): randomize()
_r = doRandom
# now, for extra credit Ñ increase the number of particles to 1,000,000. You'll probably find that you can't update them live at a great framerate, but you can still move the camera around (or set shader uniforms) when you are not updating them. This is because moving things to the graphics card (and computing that Rand) is expensive, but drawing them isn't. Ultimately you want to do things like 'randomize' on the graphics card itself Ñ with some serious GLSLang shaders.

label= """a more advanced demo ---Êincluding some embedded pure-java""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

label= """a simple demo --- start here""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1
